paintings.title: The Creation of Adam
paintings.author: Michelangelo Buonarroti
paintings.location: Vatican City, Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel
paintings.subject: God touching Adam’s finger
paintings.extra: Michelangelo wanted to immortalize the moment when the Creator is about to physically touch his creature and transfer the spark of life to Adam. Restored in 1994

paintings.title: American Gothic
paintings.author: Grant Wood
paintings.location: USA, Chicago, Art Institute of Chicago
paintings.subject: A farmer holding a pitchfork next to his daughter

paintings.title: The Kiss
paintings.author: Gustav Klimt
paintings.subject: Two lovers embracing in an intense kiss

paintings.title: Liberty Leading the People
paintings.author: Eugène Delacroix
paintings.subject: A woman leading the people to revolt while carrying a French flag

paintings.title: The Mona Lisa
paintings.author: Leonardo da Vinci
paintings.subject: A half-length seated woman, with her face turned toward the viewer

paintings.title: Girl with a Pearl Earring
paintings.author: Jan Vermeer
paintings.subject: A young girl with her face turned toward the viewer, wearing a pearl earring, an ochre-colored cloak, and a blue turban

paintings.title: The Scream
paintings.author: Edvard Munch
paintings.location: Norway, Oslo, National Museum of Art, Architecture and Design
paintings.style: Oil, tempera, and pastel on cardboard
paintings.subject: A man screaming in despair and confusion as a reflection of the universal human condition

paintings.title: Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
paintings.author: Georges Seurat
paintings.location: USA, Chicago, Art Institute of Chicago
paintings.subject: People relaxing on the banks of the island of La Grande Jatte, just outside Paris

paintings.title: Self-Portrait with Grey Felt Hat
paintings.author: Vincent Van Gogh
paintings.subject: A man with a grey felt hat

paintings.title: The Birth of Venus
paintings.author: Sandro Botticelli
paintings.subject: Painting inspired by the myth of the goddess Venus; despite the title, the work depicts her arrival on the island of Cyprus
